Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339, 162 N.E. 99 (1928) (proximate cause and foreseeability principles heavily cited in Massachusetts decisions).
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339, 162 N.E. 99 (1928) (proximate cause and foreseeability principles heavily cited in Massachusetts decisions).
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf squarely addresses the concepts of foreseeability and the relational nature of duty and proximate cause, which is why it is heavily cited for those principles, including by Massachusetts courts. Cardozo’s opinion frames negligence and proximate cause in terms of the scope of foreseeable risk to the particular plaintiff, and explicitly downplays causation analysis in favor of foreseeability-based duty. Thus the case is accurately cited as authority for proximate cause and foreseeability principles.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… These cases aside, wrong is defined in terms of the natural or probable, at least when unintentional… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us. The question of liability is always anterior to the question of the measure of the consequences that go with liability.”

Phillips v. Worcester, 358 Mass. 111 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion in Phillips v. Worcester as provided is not a negligence case and does not discuss duty, foreseeability, or any tort principles. It concerns whether a fraternal benefit society is exempt from Massachusetts sales and use taxes under specific statutory provisions. Because the court’s analysis is confined to tax incidence and statutory construction, it does not support a proposition about duty and foreseeability in negligence law.
Phillips v. Worcester, 358 Mass. 111 (19.relevant_excerpt: “We see no reason, however, for changing our conclusion on the incidence of the sales tax in a situation where Federal immunity from State taxation is not involved. It follows that the incidence of the sales tax on the goods purchased in Massachusetts is not upon Royal Arcanum, and that there is therefore no basis for an exemption.”

Glancy v. Taunton, 350 Mass. 150 (1965).raw_text: Glancy v. Taunton, 350 Mass. 150 (1965) (duty of care).
Glancy v. Taunton, 350 Mass. 150 (1965).proposition: Glancy v. Taunton, 350 Mass. 150 (1965) (duty of care).
Glancy v. Taunton, 350 Mass. 150 (1965).case_name: Attorney Gen. v. President & Fellows of Harvard College
Glancy v. Taunton, 350 Mass. 150 (1965).support_reasoning: The provided text is not Glancy v. Taunton at all, but a different Massachusetts case involving the Arnold Arboretum and Harvard’s administration of a charitable trust. It discusses trustee duties in administering a public charitable trust, not the duty of care at issue in Glancy v. Taunton. Because the opinion excerpt does not match the cited case and does not address the specific duty-of-care principle associated with Glancy, it cannot be said to support that proposition.
Glancy v. Taunton, 350 Mass. 150 (1965).relevant_excerpt: "The plain obligation of the members of the Corporation was to bring to bear the attention and judgment required of trustees in the performance of their trust duties on the issue of the effect of the move on the continued accomplishment of the express purposes of the trust and to act in a way that they believed in their good judgment would promote those purposes. We hold that the findings show that they did so act."

Kelley v. Metropolitan Transit Authority.raw_text: Kelley v. Metropolitan Transit Authority, 382 Mass. 1 (1980) (proximate cause and foreseeability).
Kelley v. Metropolitan Transit Authority.proposition: Kelley v. Metropolitan Transit Authority, 382 Mass. 1 (1980) (proximate cause and foreseeability).
Kelley v. Metropolitan Transit Authority.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about rape, identification evidence, an alibi supported by institutional records, and the standard for granting a new trial based on the weight of the evidence. It does not analyze or apply doctrines of proximate cause or foreseeability in tort or negligence; those concepts do not appear in the reasoning. Therefore it does not support a proposition about proximate cause and foreseeability and appears to be a miscitation for that purpose.
Kelley v. Metropolitan Transit Authority.relevant_excerpt: “On the motion for a new trial, made after the jury had brought in their verdicts, the judge had his opportunity to consider whether the verdicts were against the weight of the evidence, that is, so far against the general current of the evidence that to allow the verdicts to stand without retrial would involve a serious risk of perpetrating an injustice — here the risk of a false conviction based on what the defendant contends is a classic case of mistaken identity.”

Lyons v. Worcester, 404 Mass. 1 (1989) (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lyons v. The text contains no analysis of proximate cause, foreseeability, or related tort or criminal causation standards. Therefore, this case, as quoted, does not support a proposition about causation and foreseeability.
Lyons v. Worcester, 404 Mass. 1 (1989) (.relevant_excerpt:
There being no evidence of prosecutorial overreaching, the defendants have not shown that their retrial was barred on double jeopardy grounds. There was no error in the denial of the motions to dismiss.

2. Second trial. The defendant Smith claims four errors in the second trial... [discussion of closing argument, burden of proof, etc.].

Additionally, the judge gave proper instructions as to the burden of proof and to the effect that opening and closing arguments are not evidence. There was no reversible error.

Gaffney v. Aronson, 365 Mass. 167 (1974).raw_text: Gaffney v. Aronson, 365 Mass. 167 (1974) (concerning comparative negligence concepts).
Gaffney v. Aronson, 365 Mass. 167 (1974).proposition: Gaffney v. Aronson, 365 Mass. 167 (1974) (concerning comparative negligence concepts).
Gaffney v. Aronson, 365 Mass. 167 (1974).support_reasoning: The quoted text from Gaffney v. Aronson contains only concurring opinions in an obscenity-statute case and does not discuss negligence, comparative negligence, or tort liability at all. Therefore, this opinion as provided does not and cannot support any proposition about comparative negligence concepts, and the citation is inapposite for that purpose.
Gaffney v. Aronson, 365 Mass. 167 (1974).relevant_excerpt: The United States Supreme Court, in the Miller case, ruled that the Constitution requires specificity in an obscenity statute. More particularly, the relevant sexual conduct must be specifically defined either in the wording of the statute or by authoritative judicial construction of the statute. Clearly G. L. c. 272, § 28A, contains no such specifics in its wording. Nor have we authoritatively construed the statute.

Arrington v. Wicked Boston Bus Co., 430.relevant_excerpt: The defendant appeals from his conviction of murder in the first degree under the theories of deliberate premeditation, felony-murder, and extreme atrocity or cruelty. Amaral v. DeMartino, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 5.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns lease obligations in a commercial percentage-rent context, implied covenants to continue operating a business, and the reasonableness of a landlord’s refusal to consent to a sublease. It does not address allocation of fault in vehicle collisions or any tort or negligence principles related to motor vehicle accidents. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for the stated proposition about allocation of fault in vehicle collisions.
Amaral v. DeMartino, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 5.relevant_excerpt: “This appeal concerns the obligations of parties to a long-term commercial lease for a retail store, percentage rent being an important feature, when the tenant, for business reasons, seeks to relocate during the course of the lease term… Whether a lessor acts reasonably in withholding his consent to a sublease, therefore, is a question for the finder of fact.”

MacDonald v. The City, 376 Mass. 496 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is an administrative and education-law case about Massachusetts’ Chapter 766 special education scheme, addressing the powers of the Bureau of Special Education Appeals, parental reimbursement, and school committee obligations. It does not analyze municipal or civil negligence, duty, breach, causation, or tort liability principles. Citing this decision as authority for general municipal/civil negligence analysis would therefore be inaccurate and unsupported by the holding or reasoning in the case.
MacDonald v. The City, 376 Mass. 496 (19.relevant_excerpt: "For the reasons discussed below, we answer the first two reported questions in the affirmative. As to the third question, we conclude that retroactive reimbursement to parents who have provided necessary services at their own expense, from the date at which they rejected the school committee’s inadequate plan, is consistent with the statutory scheme."
